image.altText: Anthony Albanese speaks at a media conference in front of the Australian flag

items.synopsis: Commissioner Catherine Holmes faced the unenviable task of reviewing about a million tendered documents and hundreds of hours of evidence over nine weeks of public hearings. Follow live.

title.children: PM says Robodebt commission revealed a ‘gross betrayal and a human tragedy’

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: He says the government will "carefully consider" the recommendations made by Commissioner Catherine Holmes. "I particularly want to acknowledge the many thousands of individuals who were harmed by the Robodebt scheme and thank those who bravely share their stories with the commission," he says. "You ensured the voices of those affected and their families were heard. We have arrived at the truth because of the courage of some of the most vulnerable Australians. "People who have shown bravery in the face of injustice, hardship and sometimes terrible grief. The courage stands in stark contrast to those who sought to shift the blame, bury the truth and carry on justifying the shocking harm."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'It should never have happened, and it should never happen again': Anthony Albanese

mediaThumbnail.caption: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the report from the Royal Commission into the failed scheme shows it was wrong, illegal, and should never have happened.

document.title: PM says report shows Robodebt a "gross betrayal and a human tragedy"

children.content: He says the government will "carefully consider" the recommendations made by Commissioner Catherine Holmes.
"I particularly want to acknowledge the many thousands of individuals who were harmed by the Robodebt scheme and thank those who bravely share their stories with the commission," he says.
"You ensured the voices of those affected and their families were heard. We have arrived at the truth because of the courage of some of the most vulnerable Australians.

"People who have shown bravery in the face of injustice, hardship and sometimes terrible grief. The courage stands in stark contrast to those who sought to shift the blame, bury the truth and carry on justifying the shocking harm."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Commissioner Holmes concludes her Robodebt overview in the report by saying: "Robodebt was a crude and cruel mechanism, neither fair nor legal, and it made many people feel like criminals. In essence, people were traumatised on the off-chance they might owe money. It was a costly failure of public administration, in both human and economic terms."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'It made many people feel like criminals'

children.content: concludes her Robodebt overview in the report by saying:

"Robodebt was a crude and cruel mechanism, neither fair nor legal, and it made many people feel like criminals. In essence, people were traumatised on the off-chance they might owe money. It was a costly failure of public administration, in both human and economic terms."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The report makes 57 recommendations, categorised into: Effects of Robodebt on individuals The concept of vulnerability The roles of advocacy groups and legal services Experiences of Human Services employees Failures in the Budget process Data-matching and exchanges Automated decision making Debt recovery and debt collectors Lawyers and legal services Administrative Appeals Tribunal The Commonwealth Ombudsman Improving the Australian Public Service More details to come. If you want to read the 990-page report yourself, it's now available here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The final report of the Royal Commission into the Robodebt Scheme has been tabled

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The ASX has fallen by close to 2 per cent at the start of trade, following Wall Street's lead after strong labour market data out of the US increased the likelihood of a Federal Reserve rate hike to curb inflation. Follow live.

title.children: ASX suffers biggest daily loss since March after rate hike fears cause sharp losses on Wall Street

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More than two hours into the local session now things remain fairly bleak — 189 of the top 200 stocks are in the red. And it's not just the local share market that's following the overnight losses — stocks across Asia have also fallen and New Zealand's market is off by 0.9 per cent. Here's a look at the biggest moves on the ASX 200 so far: Bottom 5 Pinnacle Investment Mgmt: -6.2% Block: -5.3% Magellan: -5.2% Capricorn Metals: -4.6% Ingenia Communities: -4.6% Top 5 Regis Resources: +1.8% Amcor: +1% NRW Holdings: +0.4% News Corp: +0.4% Coronado Global Resources: +0.3% Every sector of the market is posting losses as it stands. It follows a sell-off on bond markets overnight, as unexpectedly strong economic data out of the US stoked fears of further rate hikes there.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX and stocks around the region in the red

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former ACTU vice president Anna Booth has been appointed as the new Fair Work Ombudsman by the federal government, replacing Sandra Parker. Ms Booth was previously the deputy president of the Fair Work Commission from 2012 to 2020, and was recently appointed by the NSW government to co-chair a new industrial relations taskforce. Outgoing FWO, Ms Parker, will finish her term on July 14, before Ms Booth begins on September 1. Deputy Fair Work Ombudsman, Kristen Hannah, will be the Acting Fair Work Ombudsman in the interim before Ms Booth's term starts.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal government appoints new Fair Work Ombudsman

children.content: Former ACTU vice president Anna Booth has been appointed as the new Fair Work Ombudsman by the federal government, replacing Sandra Parker.
Ms Booth was previously the deputy president of the Fair Work Commission from 2012 to 2020, and was recently appointed by the NSW government to co-chair a new industrial relations taskforce.
Outgoing FWO, Ms Parker, will finish her term on July 14, before Ms Booth begins on September 1.
Deputy Fair Work Ombudsman, Kristen Hannah, will be the Acting Fair Work Ombudsman in the interim before Ms Booth's term starts.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Viva Energy is planning to sell 23 of its sites in South Australia ahead of its proposed acquisition of On The Run (OTR) from Peregrine Corporation. The proposed sale of the 14 sites — valued at $71 million — is to appease the ACCC so the takeover deal is likely to be given the green light. Along with being a fuel refiner, importer and wholesaler, Viva Energy is also a fuel retailer and operates sites across the country — including Coles Express sites. Viva also operates Puma-branded petrol stations in the Northern Territory. Viva Energy announced its acquisition of OTR back in April in a $1.15 billion deal. OTR is a South Australian based petrol station and convenience store, and has more than 160 locations across SA and Victoria. The ACCC is currently reviewing the proposed deal, with the investigation focused on whether the takeover will impact competition and lead to higher fuel or retail prices. Findings from the ACCC into the deal are set to be announced in September.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Viva Energy to sell SA sites ahead of OTR takeover

props.alt: A petrol station with a convenience store attached.

children.content: OTR is a South Australian-based petrol station and convenience store chain.
Viva Energy is planning to sell 23 of its sites in South Australia ahead of its proposed acquisition of On The Run (OTR) from Peregrine Corporation.
The proposed sale of the 14 sites — valued at $71 million — is to appease the ACCC so the takeover deal is likely to be given the green light.

Along with being a fuel refiner, importer and wholesaler, Viva Energy is also a fuel retailer and operates sites across the country — including Coles Express sites. Viva also operates Puma-branded petrol stations in the Northern Territory.
Viva Energy announced its acquisition of OTR back in April in a $1.15 billion deal.
OTR is a South Australian based petrol station and convenience store, and has more than 160 locations across SA and Victoria.
The ACCC is currently reviewing the proposed deal, with the investigation focused on whether the takeover will impact competition and lead to higher fuel or retail prices.
Findings from the ACCC into the deal are set to be announced in September.
